'''Adusted RevPAR''' (or '''ARPAR''', adjusted revenue per available room), is a performance metric used in the hotel industry. It is calculated by dividing the variable net revenues of a property by the total available rooms (see more formulas below).<ref>{{cite web|title=7 Methods for Measuring and Improving Hotel Performance|url=https://www.amadeus-hospitality.com/insight/measuring-and-improving-hotel-performance/|website=Amadeus Hospitality|accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
The difference between ARPAR and other metrics ([[RevPAR]], [[TRevPAR]], [[GOPPAR]]) is that it accounts for variable costs and additional revenues.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sunny|first1=Kiran|title=Neither revPAR nor occupancy are ideal indicators of hotel profitability – it’s all about the ARPAR!|url=https://www.hospitalitynet.org/opinion/4077407.html|website=HospitalityNet|publisher=Hotelogix|accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
==Calculations== Various formulas can be used to calculate ARPAR<ref>{{cite book|last1=Vouk|first1=Ira|title=REVENUE MANAGEMENT MADE EASY, for Midscale and Limited-Service Hotels: The 6 Strategic Steps for Becoming the Most Valuable Person at Your Property.|date=Mar 31, 2018|publisher=Ira Vouk Revenue Management Services|isbn=978-1-387-70254-1|pages=18-19}}</ref>
* (Room Revenue + Other Revenues – VarCPOR х Number of occupied rooms) / Total Number of rooms available for sale
* (Room Revenue/Number of occupied rooms + Other Revenues/Number of occupied rooms – VarCPOR) x Occupancy
* [(Room Revenue/Number of occupied rooms + Other Revenues/Number of occupied rooms – VarCPOR) х Number of occupied rooms] / (Number of rooms at the hotel x Number of days in the period)
where VarCPOR is Variable Costs per Occupied Room
The most commonly used formula is:
*ARPAR = (ADR – Var costs per occ room + Additional revenues per occ room) x Occupancy<ref>{{cite web|title=From RevPAR to TRevPAR – how profitable is your hotel?|url=https://www.customer-alliance.com/en/articles/revpar/|website=Customer Alliance Resources|accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=ADR, Occupancy Rate, RevPar, ARPar|url=https://quizlet.com/186158756/adr-occupancy-rate-revpar-arpar-flash-cards/|website=Quizlet|accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
==How it compares to RevPAR== ARPAR accounts for variable costs and additional revenues, thus it reflects the profit (bottom line) versus top line revenue.
==How it compares to GOPPAR== GOPPAR accounts for all costs (not only variable) and is retroactive. ARPAR considers revenues from all departments and only var costs and can be used in forecasts.
==Conditions== * There is no standard formula for CPOR (cost per occupied room) in the industry and no standardization in regards to separating variable costs from fixed, which requires approximation when calculating VarCPOR. However, these calculations are only performed once. * Due to the above, ARPAR of each individual property can not be compared to others and is intended for internal use only.

'''Ale Smidts''' (born 1958) is a Dutch organizational theorist, and Professor of Marketing Research at the [[Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University]] (RSM). known for his work on [[organizational identification]],<ref>Riketta, Michael. "Organizational identification: A meta-analysis." Journal of Vocational Behavior 66.2 (2005): 358-384.</ref> and [[neuromarketing]].<ref>Boricean, Veronica. "Brief history of neuromarketing." ICEA-FAA Bucharest (2009).</ref>
== Life and work == Smidts grew up in Leeuwarden, where he attended the Lienward College. He obtained his MS at the [[Wageningen University and Research Centre]] in 1982, and in 1986 his PhD.<ref name="AS 2015">"Ale Smidts, Professor of Marketing Research," at Linkedin.com, 2015</ref>
After his graduation Smidts started his academic career at the Wageningen University. In 1997 he was appointed Professor of Marketing Research at the Rotterdam School of Management, where he also chairs the Department of Marketing Management. From 2004 to 2011 he was also Scientific Director of the [[Erasmus Research Institute of Management]] (ERIM). Since 2005 he also is Director of the Erasmus Center for Neuroeconomics.<ref name="AS 2015"/>
His research interests are in the fields of [[neuroscience]], [[neuroeconomics]] and particularly [[neuromarketing]].<ref name="AS 2015"/>
== Selected publications == * Pruyn, Ad, and Ale Smidts. "Effects of waiting on the satisfaction with the service: Beyond objective time measures." ''International Journal of Research in Marketing'' 15.4 (1998): 321-334. * Pennings, Joost ME, and Ale Smidts. "Assessing the construct validity of risk attitude." ''Management Science'' 46.10 (2000): 1337-1348. * Smidts, Ale, Ad Th H. Pruyn, and [[Cees B.M. Van Riel]]. "[http://repub.eur.nl/pub/10/erimrs20000321133141.pdf The impact of employee communication and perceived external prestige on organizational identification]." ''Academy of Management journal'' 44.5 (2001): 1051-1062. * Leenheer, J., Van Heerde, H. J., Bijmolt, T. H., & Smidts, A. (2007). "[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Harald_Van_Heerde/publication/232906169_Do_loyalty_programs_really_enhance_behavioral_loyalty_An_empirical_analysis_accounting_for_self-selecting_members/links/0fcfd509893f8168d6000000.pdf Do loyalty programs really enhance behavioral loyalty? An empirical analysis accounting for self-selecting members]." ''International Journal of Research in Marketing,'' 24(1), 31-47. * Klucharev, V., Hytönen, K., Rijpkema, M., Smidts, A., & Fernández, G. (2009). "[http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0896627308010209 Reinforcement learning signal predicts social conformity]." ''Neuron,'' 61(1), 140-151. == References == {{Reflist|2}}

{{Infobox person | name = Alessandro Picardi | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1977}} | nationality = Italian | occupation = Italian manager }} '''Alessandro Picardi''' (born 1977) is an Italian manager.
== Biography == Alessandro Picardi is an executive manager. Currently is President of Tivùsat,<ref>[https://www.tvdigitaldivide.it/tivu-nuovo-cda-e-alessandro-picardi-presidente/ Tivù, nuovo Cda e Alessandro Picardi presidente]</ref> Director of the Strategic Development of Rai platforms and a member of the General Council of Confindustria Radio Televisioni.<ref>[https://www.corrierecomunicazioni.it/digital-economy/confindustria-radio-tv-conferma-franco-siddi-alla-presidenza/ Confindustria Radio-Tv conferma Franco Siddi alla presidenza]</ref> He was of Rai Director of the Institutional and International Relations<ref>[http://www.economiaoggi.it/Tecnologia/rai-alessandro-picardi-e-direttore-delle-relazioni-istituzionali-e-internazionali.html RAI: ALESSANDRO PICARDI È DIRETTORE DELLE RELAZIONI ISTITUZIONALI E INTERNAZIONALI]</ref><ref>[https://www.megamodo.com/alessandro-picardi-direttore-delle-relazioni-istituzionali-e-internazionali-della-rai/ ALESSANDRO PICARDI, DIRETTORE DELLE RELAZIONI ISTITUZIONALI E INTERNAZIONALI DELLA RAI]</ref><ref>[http://www.businesspeople.it/People/People-moving/Picardi-e-il-nuovo-direttore-Relazioni-istituzionali-della-Rai_47713 Picardi è il nuovo direttore Relazioni istituzionali della Rai]</ref><ref>[http://e-duesse.it/News/Televisione/Picardi-e-il-nuovo-direttore-Relazioni-istituzionali-della-Rai-151704 PICARDI È IL NUOVO DIRETTORE RELAZIONI ISTITUZIONALI DELLA RAI]</ref> from 2013 to October 2016 and board member of Auditel from 2015 to 2018.<ref>[http://www.dailyonline.it/auditel-andrea-imperiali-confermato-presidente-per-il-triennio-2018-2020-dal-30-di-luglio-saranno-disponibili-i-dati-del-superpanel/ Auditel: Andrea Imperiali confermato presidente per il triennio 2018-2020; dal 30 di luglio saranno disponibili i dati del “Superpanel”]</ref>
He graduated in media studies at Link Campus University in Rome and he is also a journalist registered in the national list of publicists. Member of executive board of Center for American Studies.
Vice President of Corporate Affairs of Alitalia from 2012 to 2013,<ref>[http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/economia/arrivo-manager-esterni-rilancio-dellazienda-835620.html In arrivo manager esterni per il rilancio dell'azienda]</ref> Alessandro Picardi has a consolidated experience in the field of telecommunications: he was from December 2006 to August 2012 Head of Institutional Affairs at Wind Telecomunicazioni and previously, from 2004 to November 2006 at Sky Italy he worked as Institutional Affairs and Relations with the Vatican.
He was Chairman of the FUB (Fondazione Ugo Bordoni) committee, a high culture and research institute with a tradition of research and application studies in the fields of telecommunications and information technology.<ref>[https://www.sviluppoeconomico.gov.it/images/stories/documenti/fub_brochure_ott2012.pdf LA FONDAZIONE UGO BORDONI]</ref> Short-term board member of “L’Orientale” University of Naples, He was also in the board of directors of Assaereo and Asstel.
== Private Life == Alessandro Picardi has been married to Beatrice Lorenzin, former Italian health minister, since September 2016.<ref>[https://www.huffingtonpost.it/2016/09/10/lorenzin-matrimonio-capri_n_11952770.html Beatrice Lorenzin sposa Alessandro Picardi. Il matrimonio del ministro della Salute a Capri]</ref> He is father of Francesco and Lavinia.

'''Dr Amyn Dahya''' (born June 28, 1957) is an [[author]], [[businessman]], and [[chemical engineer]]. He is a specialist in technology development in the area of environment protection and preservation. He is also the author of seven books.<ref>{{cite web|title=Amazon Amyn Dahya Books|url=https://www.amazon.com/Books-Amyn-Dahya/s?ie=UTF8&page=1&rh=n%3A283155%2Cp_27%3AAmyn%20Dahya}}</ref>
==Early career== Born and raised in East [[Africa]], Dr Amyn entered the world of business at the tender age of eleven, when he sold fresh eggs from the family farm to the tourist hotels along the coastline of [[Mombasa]], on his way to school each day.<ref>{{cite web|title=Empowered Living Foundation|url=http://empoweredlivingfoundation.com/mentor/the-mentor/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Amyn Dahya Facebook Page|url=https://www.facebook.com/pg/amyn.dahya.2/about/?ref=page_internal}}</ref>
Dr. Amyn later graduated with a First Class Honors degree from [[Aston University]] in [[Birmingham]], [[United Kingdom]]. He is also a licensed [[Chemical Engineer]] in [[Ontario]] and [[New Brunswick]], [[Canada]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Amyn Dahya LinkedIn|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/dr-amyn-dahya-55129728/}}</ref> He has over 35 years of experience in the development of minerals and environmental projects internationally: covering plant design, research, engineering, construction, commissioning, operations management, corporate and project financing, mergers and acquisitions.<ref>{{cite web|title=MENA Water Resources World Conference|url=http://www.cmtevents.com/speakerprofiles.aspx?EV=100104&spid=144492&}}</ref>
He is member of the Board of Directors of Environmental Technology and Management Association (ETMA) in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr Amyn Dahya LinkedIn|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/dr-amyn-dahya-55129728/}}</ref>
==Books== Dr Amyn underwent a spiritual awakening after a life-threatening accident in Kashmir in 1987. He has since penned seven books and teaches meditation for self growth, healing and balance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr Amyn Dahya Website|url=http://www.amyndahya.com/about/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dr Amyn Dahya Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/amyndahya?lang=en}}</ref>
His work includes:
* ''Invoked'' (2010)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Invoked-Amyn-Dahya/dp/190442824X|title=Invoked|last=Dahya|first=Amyn|date=2010|publisher=Shift Publications|isbn=9781904428244|language=English}}</ref> * ''The Alacanzera Rise Again'' (2006) {{ISBN|978-1904428206}} * ''Towards Zero Conflict: Begins With You'' (2005) {{ISBN|978-1904428244}} * ''Be and It Is: Inspirations of Empowerment: 1'' (2002) {{ISBN|978-1904428084}}<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Be-Inspirations-Empowerment-Amyn-Dahya/dp/1904428088|title=Be and It Is: Inspirations of Empowerment: 1|last=Dahya|first=Amyn|date=2002-12-13|publisher=Empowered Living Foundation|isbn=9781904428084|edition=1st|language=English}}</ref> * ''Reflections From the Origin'' (1997) {{ISBN|978-0968268315}} <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Reflections-Origin-Amyn-Dahya/dp/0968268315|title=Reflections from the Origin|last=Dahya|first=Amyn|date=1998-01-01|publisher=Reflections Publishing|isbn=9780968268315|edition=First|location=Vancouver|language=English}}</ref> * ''Parables from the Origin'' (1999) {{ISBN|978-0968268322}} <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Parables-Origin-Amyn-Dahya/dp/0968268323|title=Parables from the Origin|last=Dahya|first=Amyn|date=1999-12-31|publisher=Imprint unknown|isbn=9780968268322|edition=Revised|location=Vancouver|language=English}}</ref>

[[File:Fukuhara arinobu.jpg|thumb]] {{nihongo|'''Arinobu Fukuhara'''|福原 有信|Fukuhara Arinobu|May 10, 1848 – March 30, 1924}} was a Japanese businessman and pharmacist, who was the head of Apothecary Shiseidō (which in 1927 would be incorporated as [[Shiseido|Shiseidō]]) and {{nihongo|Toku Fukuhara|福原 とく|Fukuhara Toku}}. In addition, this businessman's name is known internationally because of the Arinobu Fukuhara House at [[Hakone]], which [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] designed in 1918 as a Prairie-style vacation villa for the extended Fukuhara family.<ref>Wright in Japan: [http://www.wrightinjapan.org/eng_waaj/e_buildings/dsgn08fukuhara_e.html Arinobu Fukuhara House]</ref>
Born in Awa, Chiba-ken, he rose in due course to become Chief Pharmacist of the [[Imperial Japanese Navy]]. In retirement, he embarked on a second career which would bring fame and fortune. He was also president of the [[Aikoko Insurance Company]].<ref>Takenobu Yoshitarō and Yoshitaro Takenobu. (1905). [https://books.google.com/books?id=HblKAAAAMAAJ&q=arinobu+Fukuhara&dq=arinobu+Fukuhara&lr=&pgis=1 ''The Japan Year Book,'' p. 59.] Tokyo: Japan Yearbook Office.</ref>
== Family patriarch == Arinobu was the father of photographers {{nihongo|[[Rosō Fukuhara]]|福原 路草|Fukuhara Rosō|1892–1946}}, {{nihongo|[[Shinzō Fukuhara]]|福原 信三|Fukuhara Shinzō|1883–1948}} and {{nihongo|[[Nobuyushi Fukuhara]]|福原 信義|Fukuhara Nobuyushi|1897–1958}}, who would gain fame as {{nihongo|[[Tōru Namiki]]|並木 透|Namiki Tōru}}.<ref>Tokyo Art Beat: [http://www.tokyoartbeat.com/event/2005/DFFB.en "Masters of Light – Photographic Works of Shinzo, Nobutatsu and Nobuyoshi Fukuhara"]</ref> His sons became quintessential ''mobo'', or "modern boys"—the sobriquet coined to describe the young, sophisticated, up-to-date young men who frequented the fashionable Ginza district in the late 1920s<ref>Kramer, Eric Mark. (2003). [https://books.google.com/books?id=x9-yOGSyKrYC&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=Arinobu+Fukuhara+&source=web&ots=1pVazJRDvK&sig=T5rD73aesjNTzgRvSFC7JjijjgE&hl=en#PPA60,M1 ''The Emerging Monoculture: Assimilation and the "Model Minority,'' p. 60.]</ref>—and they shared a fascination and persistent attraction to photography as an art form. The Fukuharas helped to bring photography into the mainstream of Japanese modernism.<ref>[http://www.nyu.edu/greyart/exhibits/shiseido/history.htm ''mobo'' (modern boys) sobriquet]</ref> The two brothers were founding organizers of the {{nihongo|[[Japan Photographic Society (1924–)|Japan Photographic Society]]|日本写真会<ref>Alternate ''kanji'', in the orthography of the time of its foundation: 日本寫眞會.</ref>|Nihon Shashinkai}} in 1924; and Shinzō was its first president.<ref>Colberg blog: [http://www.jmcolberg.com/weblog/2003/05/ Rosō & Shinzō Fukuhara]</ref> The organization was a major pre-war influence on Japanese photography and still exists today despite a temporary dissolution during the years of the Pacific War.<ref>PhotoGuide Japan: [http://photojpn.org/news/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=35 Fukuhara Shinzo] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001133243/http://photojpn.org/news/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=35 |date=October 1, 2006 }}</ref>
Grandson {{nihongo|[[Yoshiharu Fukuhara]]|福原義春|Fukuhara Yoshiharu|1931–}} continues this family tradition of fostering the development of Japanese photography. He has been Director of the [[Tokyo Metropolitan Museum of Photography]] since his appointment by Tokyo Governor [[Shintarō Ishihara]] in 2000.<ref>PhotoGuide Japan: [http://photojpn.org/news/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=36 Fukuhara Yoshiharu] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001133449/http://photojpn.org/news/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=36 |date=October 1, 2006 }}</ref>
== Shiseido == {{quote|Beauty is universal, thus the products which serve beauty should also be universal.|Yushin Fukuhara, company founder}}
As Shiseido has grown to become an international cosmetics giant, the company has managed to avoid some of the pitfalls and problems which have attended generational transitions in other successful family businesses.<ref>Kenyon -Rouvinez, Denise. (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=AbfTcruXZnAC&pg=PA87&lpg=PA87&dq=arinobu+fukuhara&source=web&ots=RjONsarzz5&sig=e5D8PYxnV07PQWPbzH1RHYBZo4Y&hl=en#PPA89,M1 "Sharing Wisdom, Building Values: Letters from Family Business Owners to their Successors,'' p. 89.]</ref> For example, Arinobu's grandson, Yoshiharu Fukuhara, joined Shiseido immediately after receiving his B.A. in economics from Keio University, Tokyo, in 1953. He was appointed President & CEO of Shiseido in 1987, then Chairman of the Board in 1997 and Honorary Chairman in 2001.<ref>[http://ocw.dmc.keio.ac.jp/Alumni_essay_1.html Keio alumni essay]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Three Fukuhara leaders in the Shiseido hierarchy were: * 1st President: Fukuhara, Shinzo—son of company founder * 2nd President: Fukuhara, Nobuyoshi—younger brother of company's 1st president * 3rd President: Fukuhana, Yoshibaru—son of company's 2nd president
== Japan Pharmaceutical Association == Arinobu served as the third president of the {{nihongo|[[Japan Pharmaceutical Association]]|日本薬剤師会|''Nippon Yakuzaishi Kai''}}, 1907–1909.<ref>Japan Pharmaceutical Assn.: [http://www.nichiyaku.or.jp/e/e3.html JPA presidents]</ref> During his administration, JPA applied for and obtained approval from the Japanese government to become what was known as a "corporate juridical person" (public corporation).<ref>Japan Pharmaceutical Assn.: [http://www.nichiyaku.or.jp/e/e2.html JPA history]</ref>
== Arinobu Fukuhara House == [[File:Arinobu Fukuhara House, full view.jpg|thumb|Full view of the Arinobu Fukuhara House]] The commissioned house was designed and built in 1920, but the site near a hot spring left the building vulnerable to the cataclysmic [[1923 Great Kantō earthquake]] which collapsed it.

The '''Australian Shareholders' Association''' ('''ASA''') is an independent, member-funded, '''not-for-profit''' organisation that has grown to be the major autonomous body representing Australian retail investors.
The ASA's main mission is ''''''Standing up for shareholders''''''.
Since 1960 the ASA has been protecting and advancing the interests of investors and providing a strong collective voice for shareholders. It does this by advancing the interests of retail [[shareholders]] with government, industry, the markets and individual companies - monitoring companies with the aim of improving both financial performance and corporate governance. The ASA has successfully raised the standard of corporate governance in Australian companies and continues to press for improvements in transparency and accountability.
Each year the ASA monitors the performance of Australia's top 200 ASX-listed companies. The ASA's company monitoring objective is to positively influence outcomes for retail shareholders. The ASA wants all shareholders to be treated equally and advocates for change where change is due.
The ASA helps members to improve their investment knowledge and financial literacy with free member meetings, discussion groups and cost-effective education across Australia, including many regional areas. By providing independent research, governance information and well-priced education programs the ASA helps members develop practical skills to improve their investing knowledge.
==Current activities== The ASA advocates for shareholders by attending company [[annual general meeting]]s (AGMs) and engaging with government and industry bodies on behalf of shareholders. Based on engagement with company boards and independent analysis of annual reports and financial statements, company monitors prepare Voting Intentions (VIs) consistent with ASA policy. Company monitors represent the ASA at AGMs, where issues such as [[Executive pay|executive remuneration]], company performance, shareholder rights and director qualifications/workloads are discussed, and proxies voted. AGM Reports are prepared by the company monitors and are available online so members can see how Australia's leading companies are performing, and how effectively they're managed.
All shareholders are welcome to nominate the ASA as their proxy. The ASA then votes on your behalf at the company's AGM. Last year, ASA company monitors voted more than $3 billion worth of shares.
The ASA publishes a monthly magazine called EQUITY, holds regular member meetings across Australia and organises a biennial national conference.
==Industry Groups and Committees== The ASA represents shareholder and member interests on the following industry groups and committees: * ATO Personal Tax Advisory * ASIC Consumer Advisory Panel * ASIC Corporations & Market Advisory Committee * Financial Reporting Council * ASX Corporate Governance Council * Securities Registrars Association of Australia
==Achievements== The ASA has proactively promoted good corporate governance and advanced shareholder interests by: * Consistently advocating for regulatory reform (i.e. two strikes rule) regarding remuneration excesses in Australian companies, and voting against poorly structured remuneration structures. * Arguing through a long, consistent and vocal campaign in the media, by our voting intentions and especially on the floor of AGMs, for companies to move to longer-term incentive schemes. * Being the world's largest retail shareholder group voting the greatest number of proxies. * Successfully negotiating with Australian companies to increase the capped share purchase plan offered to retail shareholders. * Successfully persuading companies to send reminder emails to shareholders in the final week of a capital raising offer, substantially increasing participation. * Being the dominant voice at AGMs and, along with the $3 billion+ in undirected proxies received each year, being in a unique position to influence boards and companies on behalf of shareholders. A majority of ASX200 Chairs meet with ASA representatives prior to their AGM, allowing the ASA to make important connections and enabling influence over a company's governance and board performance. * By introducing a workload policy of 5 equivalent directorships for directors and no external directorships for CEOs. * Opposing ASX changes that would make it easier for smaller companies to list and for small to medium listed companies from being able to raise 25% of issued capital without shareholder approval.
==Membership== The ASA had 6,000 members in 2013.
==Leadership== The ASA is overseen by an experienced Board of Directors comprising a Chairman and six directors. All Board members work on a pro bono basis.

Meyers Bridge]] in the foreground), 2007]] '''Center City''' is the [[downtown]] and [[Central Business District]] of [[Allentown, Pennsylvania]], in the [[United States]]. It has a dense population and is currently undergoing an [[Urban renewal|urban revitalizaton]] process.
==Boundaries== Allentown's Center City is centered at Hamilton Street and Seventh Street, and bounded by [[Little Lehigh Creek]] in the east, Martin Luther King Jr. Drive to the south, the city line with [[Whitehall Township, Pennsylvania|Whitehall]] to the north, and 15th Street to the west.
==Demographics== Center City's population based on a 2007 estimate was 53,548. The area of Center City is defined as 6.271 sq. mi., making the population density 8539/sq. mi.
==Neighborhood features== [[File:AllentownPA Skyline.jpg|thumb|right|300px|View of Allentown's Center City, 2008]] Center City's tallest building is the [[PPL Building]] at 322 ft (98 m). The [[Allentown Art Museum]], [[Allentown Symphony Hall]], the former site of [[Hess's]] Department Stores' original and flagship store, [[Baum School of Art]], [[Lehigh County Historical Society]] and Heritage Museum, and The [[Liberty Bell Museum]] are all known landmarks in Center City. A hockey arena was opened in August, 2014 near the PPL building, after emerging from a brief stall after a tax of Allentown workers was repealed, although construction is much slower.
==Additional neighborhoods== Within Center City, Allentown, there are additional neighborhoods. 7th Street, Downtown, Old Allentown, Old Fairgrounds District, and NOTI (North of Tilghman Street) are all located within Center City.
==Economy== Center City is home to the corporate headquarters of [[PPL (utility)|PPL]] and the local offices of ''[[The Morning Call]]''. [[File:2007 - PPL Building.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The tallest building in Allentown is the [[PPL Building]] at 23 stories.]]

{{Chinese name|[[Cheah]]}} '''Cheah Cheang Lim''' ({{zh|c=謝昌林|p=Xiè Chānglín}}; 6 December 1875 – 15 November 1948) was born in [[Taiping, Perak]], [[Malaysia]]. Brought up by his father, Cheah Boon Hean, who was in the trading business, he grew up to become a businessman and miner. He was introduced to the [[tin mining]] industries of the time by his cousin [[Foo Choo Choon]], the 'Tin King',<ref>Ho Tak Ming, ''When Tin was King''. Ipoh: Ho Tak Ming, 2000. {{ISBN|978-983-42500-2-7}}</ref> who hired him as his attorney. Later, Cheah Cheang Lim was appointed to manage his affairs. Eventually, he started his own company. He also invested in rubber estates but his main interest remained in the tin business.
Cheah was also known as a social reformer whose concerns were spread across various issues. He was involved in the [[anti-opium movement]] and campaigned for Chinese status in the [[Federated Malay States|Malay States]], including such efforts as debating against the [[Banishment Enactment]] to non-Malays born in the States. He furthermore dedicated his life to promoting and improving Malayan education by instituting several scholarship schemes, including the [[Queen's Scholar (British Malaya and Singapore)|Queen's Scholar]]ships in British Malaya<ref>Wu Lien-Teh & Ng Yok-Hing, ''The Queen's Scholarships of Malaya, 1885–1948''. Penang: Penang Premier Press Co. Ltd., 1949.</ref> and through donations.<ref name=lifeandtimes>Francis Cooray & Khoo Salma Nasution, ''Redoutable Reformer: The Life and Times of Cheah Cheang Lim''. Penang: Areca Books, 2015. {{ISBN|9789675719202}}</ref>
[[Volunteering]] in the Malayan Volunteer Infantry<ref>The Straits Times, 7 August 1916, Page 8. [http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19160807-1.2.41.aspx ''Malayan Volunteer Infantry'']</ref> was a significant part of his later career, as he led the younger generation in a volunteer programme. He was active in several clubs and societies across Malaysia, but mainly in [[Perak]] and [[Penang]], where he resided. He was lastly elected as a Federal Counsellor, as a representative of the Chinese population.
==Early life== Cheah Cheang Lim spent his early years in Taiping. His father was Cheah Boon Hean, son of Cheah Teah and a businessman and trader. His mother was Foo Kang Nyong. At that time, British administrative branches occupied the area, together with the [[Sikhism in Malaysia|Perak Sikhs]], the police force. The [[Residential System]] was in practice. Later, a great fire destroyed the Cheah house. The family was invited to stay at Dr. Legge's residence until Cheah Boon Hean made new arrangements.<ref name=lifeandtimes />
==Education== After attending a few temporary schools in Taiping, Cheah studied at the Central Government School, managed by Mr. J.L. Greene, now known as the [[King Edward VII School (Taiping)|King Edward VII School]], up to Standard VI. In 1889, he finished school and applied for a job at the Land Office in Taiping. He was rejected due to his age. He went back to school, became a pupil teacher and studied privately for one year.
==Career== In 1890, he became a probationer at the Posts and Telegraphs Department. Later, he went to replace a brother officer in [[Kuala Sepetang|Port Weld]] and subsequently, to his friend Joo Sip San at Lahat, Perak. Cheah was a Malay scholar and helped with English correspondence, while he also taught the staff at the Posts and Telegraphs Department to read and write in the Malay language.
In 1894, Cheah took over R. Bulner as the postmaster in [[Tanjung Malim]]. He was later transferred back to Lahat, where he resigned, as a government office no longer satisfied his ambitions. He had planned to travel to China but was offered a job as the private secretary of [[Foo Choo Choon]], his cousin, proprietor of the globally known Tronoh Mines.<ref>Arnold Wright & H.A. Cartwright, ''Twentieth Century Impressions of British Malaya: Its History, People, Commerce, Industries, and Resources''. Indiana: Repressed Publishing LLC, 2013.</ref> In 1900, he became the general manager. He worked under Foo Choo Choon for 14 years, until he decided to start his own mining business. His first mine was at Azar Dungsang.
In 1923, he was appointed a [[Justice of the peace|justice of peace]] for the State of Perak.
In 1927, he was elected as a member of the Federal Council to represent the Chinese community. He served for two terms, from 1927 to 1930 and from 1930 to 1933.
===The Anti-Opium Movement=== Cheah was an active supporter of the anti-opium movement. He was one of the founders of the [[Perak Anti-Opium Society]], which was created in December 1906, and was elected as the treasurer. A similar organization was founded in Penang, presided by Dr.[[Wu Lien-teh]]. The first Anti-Opium Conference of the [[Straits Settlements]] and [[Federated Malay States]] was held in [[Ipoh]] in 1907. It attracted around 3,000 people. The second conference was renewed in 1908 with Mr. [[Foo Choo Choon]] as the chairman. It was held in Penang, as, at that time, Penang was a significant landmark in the manufacturing and export of opium to Perak and Southern Siam.<ref name=lifeandtimes /> In addition, mass meetings were conducted during those years.
By the time the [[International Opium Convention]] Treaty was registered with the League of Nations in 1922, Cheah became the President of the Anti-Opium Society. Consequently, in October 1923, a joint Federated Malay States petition for the abolition of the [[History of opium in China|opium trade]] was strengthened by 2,000 signatures. The ban on opium was finally applied 20 years after the beginning of the campaign. Cheah had dedicated 30 years of his life to the cause.
===Benevolent works=== *1904: Donated a plot of land for the construction of the first Ipoh Maternity Hospital *1919: Instituted the Cheah Boon Hean Scholarship at his former school, King Edward VII School. *1922: Instituted the competitive Cheah Cheang Lim Scholarship in Anderson School, [[Anglo-Chinese Schools, Malaysia|Anglo-Chinese School]] and [[St. Michael's Institution]] in Ipoh. *1924: Donated $500 to Westminster College in [[Fujian]], China and was the third largest donor. *1927: Donated a classroom in the new Anglo-Chinese Girls' School
===Clubs and organizations=== *Committee member of the Perak Literary and Debating Society *Committee member of Public Health Education, Kuala Lumpur *Founding member of the Chinese Association of Malaya, [[Perak Turf Club]] and the Chinese Widows and Orphans Institution *Patron of Hu Yew Seah, Penang *President of the Radio Club, Penang
====Honorary memberships==== *Ipoh Club
====Life memberships==== *Royal Society of the Arts *Royal Empire Society *British Institute of Philosophical Studies *Ipoh Gymkhana Club (now known as the Perak Turf Club) *Garden Club, Singapore
====Memberships==== *Association of British Malaya *Red Cross Society of China *Chinese World Student Association of Shanghai *Chinese Recreation Clubs of Penang, Selangor and Perak *Chinese Chambers of Commerce of Perak and Penang *Anglo-Chinese School Union, Penang *Chinese Merchants Club, Penang *Cheang Chew Hoy Kwan, Penang *Chin Sim Seah, Ipoh *Chin Woo Seah, Ipoh *Decrepit Ward Fund, Taiping
====Trusteeships==== *Hokkien Kong Huey *Chinese Widows and Orphans Institution *Wah Yen Yee Theong (Chinese New Cemetery) *Yok Choy School *Perak Mining and Planting Association *Cheah Kongsi, Penang
===Properties=== *''Perak Lodge'' in Leith Street, [[George Town, Penang]]. *''Vihara Lodge'' in [[Jalan Tambun]], Ipoh, Perak. *Contributed to [[Penang Hill]] by building 'Westspur', a bungalow accessible via the Hill Railway. *''Adorable'' at [[Tanjung Bungah]], Penang.
===Cheah Kongsi=== Cheah belonged to the third generation of the Cheah family trustees of Cheah [[Kongsi]] (谢公司) in Penang, his grandfather and father before him. He was also appointed honorary secretary. In 1918, he revised the rules and regulations of the organization to adjust to those times. The new constitution was published in 1921. Moreover, he undertook research on the Cheah history and lineage in China, the Cheah Kongsi history and the family cemetery, and came up with a pictorial compilation.<ref>Tan Kim Hong, ''The Chinese in Penang: A Pictorial History''. Penang: Areca Books, 2007.</ref> In 1927, he was exempted from the obligation of attending the monthly meetings, due to his increasing commitment to the [[Federated Malay States]]. From 1931 to 1933, after the President, Cheah Choo Yew, died, Cheah Cheang Lim contributed to the renovation of the Cheah Kongsi. In 1934, he resigned his trusteeship, after 17 years of service, from 1917 to 1934.
===Volunteering=== In 1924, Cheah was requested by Colonel Parr to instill the [[volunteering]] spirit of the [[Peranakan|Straits Chinese]] youth.<ref name=lifeandtimes /> He thus volunteered as a second lieutenant and appointed [[Officer Commanding]] (OC), Chinese Platoon 1, in the Malayan Volunteer Infantry in Perak. In 1930, he was promoted to lieutenant.
==Family Life== In 1896, Cheah married Khoo Pek Hua, a Penang-born Straits Chinese woman. She died on 6 March 1930, due to illness and the grief of losing of three daughters within five years. She was buried at the Cheah family cemetery at [[Tikus Island|Pulau Tikus]], Penang. She left Cheang Lim with one son and one daughter, named Cheah Ghim Leng and Cheah Liew Pin, respectively. Ghim Leng was previously a sergeant in the Chinese Company of the Penang and Province Wellesley Volunteer Force, before taking over his father's business in Ipoh. Later, he was appointed Officer Commanding Chinese Platoon I, Malayan Volunteer Infantry, in Perak. In 1935, he was elected a justice of the peace. In the beginning of the year 1941, he was awarded the [[Order of the British Empire]] and became a member of the Perak State Council.
Cheah remarried in July 1930. His second wife was an English-educated lady named Khoo Chin Choo. The couple adopted a girl named Cheah Liew Khin.
==Later Years== After serving in the Federal Council, he retired from public life. He nevertheless hosted the occasional 'At Home', attended by honorable guests. Upon reaching 60 years of age, he hired Francis Cooray, author and journalist of [[The Malay Mail]] to write his biography. In 1946, he also helped in leading the formation of the second/third Penang Clerical Union<ref>The Straits Times, 12 July 1937, Page 13. [http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19370712-1.2.94.aspx ''Penang Clerks' Union To Protect Interests''.]</ref>
Cheah died on 16 November 1948, aged 77, in his home, at Leith Street, Penang. He was buried at Pulau Tikus, Penang. ''Lorong Cheah Cheang Lim'' in Ipoh, Perak is named after him.

The term '''citizen enterprise''' started to be used in the United States in 2008 to describe businesses that practice [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR).
==Information== In some countries, such as Papua New Guinea, the term is used to describe companies owned by citizens of that country, rather than by foreigners.<ref>[http://www.ipa.gov.pg/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=149&Itemid=128 The Papua New Guinea Investment Promotion Agency - Citizen, National and Foreign Enterprises]</ref>
It should not be confused with [[social enterprise]], which is a more complex notion involving origin, ownership and participation as well as objectives, activities and the use of profits.

{{orphan|date=July 2013}} '''Eastline Digital''' (formerly Eastline Marketing) is a [[digital marketing]] agency based in the [[Middle East]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.executive-magazine.com/special-report/The-top-20-Lebanese-entrepreneurs/1405|title=The Top Twenty Lebanese Entrepreneurs - Executive Magazine|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> It was one of the first companies in the [[MENA region]] to offer a full range of online marketing services such as [[social media marketing]], paid search marketing (PSM), [[search engine optimization]] (SEO) and [[online advertising]].<ref name=pleasure>{{cite news |url= http://socialmediaweek.org/beirut/tag/eastline-marketing/|title= At Eastline Marketing, work is a pleasurable challenge awaiting to be tackled!|date= |accessdate=20 June 2013}}</ref>
==History== The agency was founded in 2006 by Marc Dfouni and Nemr Nicolas Badine.<ref name=endeavor>{{cite news |url= http://endeavorlebanon.org/blog/2012/04/ees-eastline-marketing-in-the-news/|title=Eastline Marketing in the News|date= |accessdate=19 May 2013}}</ref> Prior to Eastline’s establishment, Dfouni was the general manager of a web interactive agency in [[Canada]].<ref name=dfouni>{{cite news |url=http://creativeconomy.britishcouncil.org/people/marc-dfouni/|title= Marc Dfouni – British Council’s Creative Economy Program|date= |accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> Badine meanwhile designed multimedia systems used in live performances by artists such as [[U2]], [[Paul McCartney]] and [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://eastlinemarketing.com/online-marketing-experts |title=Our Online Marketing Experts – Eastline Marketing|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> At the time of Eastline’s inception, the online marketing field was virtually nonexistent in the [[MENA]] region.<ref name=entrepreneur>{{cite news |url= http://www.emergingstars.com/success-stories/entrepreneur-serves-middle-east-one-marketing-campaign-time |title= Entrepreneur serves the Middle East one marketing campaign at a time|date= |accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://endeavorlebanon.org/blog/2013/04/risk-nothing-and-gain-nothing-how-risk-avoidance-leads-to-failure-by-nemr-nicolas-badine-%E2%80%93-co-founder-eastline-marketing/ |title= Risk Nothing and Gain Nothing - Entrepreneurship Blog|date= |accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref> However, little by little, [[Internet]] use in the [[Middle East]] began growing considerably. As a result of this, the agency started expanding its operations and working with clients based in [[Dubai]], [[Qatar]], [[Egypt]], [[Syria]] and [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.ameinfo.com/173277.html |title= Eastline Marketing Expands into MENA Region |date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref>
Eastline has developed campaigns for Middle Eastern and global brands such as [[Toyota]], [[AZADEA Group]], [[DHL]], [[Kimberly-Clark]], [[Bank Audi]], Fransabank, [[Henkel]], [[Avis Budget Group|Avis]], [[AXA Insurance]], [[Marks & Spencer]], JoueClub, and [[Waterfront City, Dubai|Waterfront City]].<ref name=entrepreneur/> It also organized and implemented a holistic online strategy for the 2009 [[Beirut Marathon]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eastlinemarketing.com/press/commerce-levant-jan-10.pdf|title= Le Marathon de Beyrouth Investit dans la Strategie Media en Ligne|date= |accessdate=1 June 2013}}</ref> The agency has produced its own web platform named Sweepz, which allows clients to launch social media promotional campaigns.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.executive-magazine.com/special-report/Naturally-selected/63?__hstc=193374066.c0c8943f24cf7a5ca932da0d5fa6d01a.1372324999380.1372324999380.1372329177422.2&__hssc=193374066.2.1372329177422|title= Naturally Selected – Executive Magazine|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> Sweepz is the only platform that supports the [[Arabic]] language.<ref name=endeavor/>
Dfouni and Badine were selected as high impact entrepreneurs by [[Endeavor (non-profit)|Endeavor]] (an [[NGO]] that supports entrepreneurs of emerging market countries) in 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.endeavor.org/entrepreneurs/nemr-nicolas-badine/1234|title= Endeavor Entrepreneurs: Nemr Nicolas Badine |date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> Dfouni was also selected as a Young Creative Entrepreneur by the [[British Council]]’s Creative Economy Programme.<ref name=dfouni/> According to Dfouni, the company’s main aim is to “become the leading digital marketing player in the [[Middle East]] by 2016”.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.endeavor.org/blog/recognizing-the-power-of-digital-dreams-eastline-marketings-founders-among-executives-top-20-entrepreneurs/|title=Eastline Marketing Founders Among Executive’s Top 20 Entrepreneurs|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref>
==Awards== Eastline Digital has garnered two [[Webby awards]] for Best Green Site and also won the People’s Voice Award.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.endeavor.org/entrepreneurs/marc-dfouni/1235/|title= Endeavor Entrepreneurs: Marc Dfouni|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> It was successful in 2010 at the [[Gemini Awards]] where it won the Best Original Program or Series Produced for Digital Media. This award was given out by the [[Academy of Canadian Cinema & Television]] for the website “Love Letters of the Future”, designed to raise public awareness of the [[2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2009 Copenhagen Summit]] and environmental issues.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.eastlinemarketing.com/online-ambassador-and-social-media-strategy-increases-online-engagement-for-love-letters-to-the-future|title=Love Letters to the Future|date= |accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> It was also a finalist at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity|Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival]] in 2010 and at the SXSW Awards.<ref name=pleasure/> In 2013, Eastline Digital's founders earned the Endeavor Advocate award at the 2013 Omidyar Network.<ref>[http://www.endeavor.org/blog/best-in-the-business-the-2013-omidyar-network-endeavor-awards-dinner/ The 2013 Omidyar Network]</ref>

[[File:Hewlett and Packard stars.jpg|thumb|Stars on the Entrepreneur Walk of Fame]]The '''Entrepreneur Walk of Fame''' was established to recognize the positive impact of entrepreneurs on job creation and technological progress.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/30/us/entrepreneur-walk-of-fame-opens-in-cambridge.html</ref> Seven honorees were unveiled in the inaugural year.<ref>http://news.bostonherald.com/jobfind/news/technology/view/20110916entrepreneur_walk_of_fame_to_honor_first_seven_tech_gods/srvc=home&position=also</ref> These were [[Bill Gates]], [[Bill Hewlett]], [[Robert A. Swanson|Bob Swanson]], [[David Packard]], [[Mitch Kapor]], [[Steve Jobs]], and [[Thomas Edison]].<ref>http://www.portfolio.com/views/blogs/the-tech-observer/2011/09/16/cambridge-unveils-entrepreneur-walk-of-fame/</ref>
New honorees are unveiled each year in the fall.<ref>http://www.geek.com/articles/geek-cetera/move-over-hollywood-the-entrepreneurial-walk-of-fame-gets-its-first-7-geeks-20110917/</ref>
The stars are located near the outbound [[Kendall Square]] [[MBTA]] [[Red Line (MBTA)|Red Line]] stop in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].<ref>http://articles.boston.com/2011-09-16/business/30165912_1_gates-and-jobs-microsoft-granite-stars</ref>

{{Infobox award | name = Fintech awards | subheader = <!-- or | current_awards = --> | image = | image_size = <!-- or | image_upright = --> | alt = | caption = Various international fintech awards | description = [[Financial technology]] | sponsor = | date = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location = <!-- or | venue = or | site = --> | country = {{Flatlist | *[[Africa]] *[[Australia]] *[[Canada]] *[[Europe]] *[[India]] *[[Italy]] *[[Luxembourg]] *[[Netherlands]] *[[Switzerland]] *[[United Kingdom]] *[[United States]]}} | acts = | reward = }} '''FinTech Awards''' are several award ceremonies, most of them unrelated, which are held all over the world to recognize excellence in [[financial technology]] as assessed by public vote and panels of judges. As a rule, there are many categories and prizes. Hundreds of companies, mostly [[startup company|startups]], participate as candidates.
As of 2016, major fintech awards ceremonies are held in [[India]], [[Australia]], [[Canada]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Netherlands|the Netherlands]], [[South Africa]], [[Switzerland]], [[United Kingdom]], and [[United States]]. Two ceremonies are not national but continental: the African FinTech Awards and Conference, and the European Fintech Awards.
==Awards by country and continent==
===Africa===
The first ''African FinTech Awards and Conference'' will be held within the Finance Indaba Africa conference and expo in [[Johannesburg]] in October 2016. It will gather [[Africa]]'s leading FinTech entrepreneurs, bankers, investors and advisors.<ref name=Africa>{{cite web |url = http://www.fintechafrica.co.za/awards.html |title = FinTech Awards & Conference Africa: Meet the African FinTech 100 |publisher = FinTech Africa |date = 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
===Australia===
The 1st ''Annual Australian FinTech Awards'' will be held on 23 June 2016. The awards will be given in thirteen categories. The project, product, research paper, campaign, or activity that is entered must have been created, developed or released in the 18 months before the awards to be a valid entry.<ref name=Fintech>{{cite web |url = http://fintechawards.net/ |title = 1st Annual Australian FinTech Awards 2016 |publisher = FinTech Awards |date = 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
Founded by Glen Frost, the founder of FinTech Summit, and sponsored by [[Ashurst LLP|Ashurst]], the awards celebrate the achievements of the people and businesses comprising the [[fintech]] sector.<ref name=Leader>{{cite web |url = http://thoughtleadership.grantthornton.com.au/post/102dbdl/recognising-the-achievements-of-the-fintech-sector |title = Recognising the achievements of the Fintech sector! |author = Madeleine Mattera |publisher = Thought Leadership |date = 19 April 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=Summit>{{cite web |url = http://fintechsummit.com.au/ |title = FinTech Summit 2016 |publisher = FinTech Summit |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref> <ref name=Meetup>{{cite web |url = http://www.meetup.com/en-AU/FinTech-Sydney/messages/boards/thread/49813040 |title = FinTech Awards 2016: now FREE to enter |author = Glen Frost |publisher = FinTech Sydney |date = 4 May 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
===Canada===
The Canadian FinTech Awards were created in 2014 by the Digital Finance Institute,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalfinanceinstitute.org|title=Digital Finance Institute|website=www.digitalfinanceinstitute.org|access-date=2016-11-03}}</ref> a prominent global think tank for FinTech created in 2013, that has helped build the Canadian FinTech ecosystem.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.digitalfinanceinstitute.org/?page_id=330|title=FinTech – Digital Finance Institute|website=www.digitalfinanceinstitute.org|access-date=2016-11-03}}</ref> The first Canadian FinTech Awards were held on October 19 2015, in Toronto as part of the Digital Finance Institute's Annual National Conference in [[Toronto]].
===Europe===
The ''European FinTech Awards'' is an organization that aims to disrupt traditional financial intuitions by providing a platform for fintech [[entrepreneur]]s to collaborate with one another.<ref name=Week>{{cite web |url = http://paymentweek.com/2016-5-5-blockchain-firm-wins-eu-fintech-award-10432/ |title = Blockchain Firm Wins EU Fintech Award |author = Ryan Kennedy |publisher = Payment Week |date = 5 May 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref> Like the Dutch and African awards, the European awards are the result of an initiative of Alex van Groningen BV, a Dutch financial publisher.<ref name=Holland>{{cite web |url = http://hollandfintech.com/dutch-isnt-holland-fintech/ |title = Why Dutch isn’t the same as Holland in FinTech |publisher = Holland Fintech |date = 5 December 2015 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
The awards start with the ''European FinTech 100'', a selection of innovative companies with ground-breaking ideas and technologies. The wide batch is chosen by the vote of more than 55,000 fintech enthusiasts from all over Europe (as of 2016). Then a panel of fintech experts reduces the selection to one hundred companies. The one hundred, in turn, are the pool from which the finalists are chosen. The finalists have the opportunity to pitch during the conference.<ref name=Egg>{{cite web |url = https://eggsplore.eu/en/blog/2016/04/european-fintech-awards-conference-2016 |title = European FinTech Awards & Conference 2016 |publisher = Eggsplore |date = 5 April 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=Euro>{{cite web |url = http://www.fintech.nl/videos-european-fintech-awards--conference-14-april-2016.html |title = Videos European FinTech Awards & Conference |publisher = European FinTech Awards |date = 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
The first European FinTech Awards & Conference was held in [[Amsterdam]] on 14 April 2016. 413 companies from 34 European countries were nominated. 30% of all nominees were from [[United Kingdom]].<ref name=Baltic>{{cite web |url = http://www.baltic-course.com/eng/good_for_business/?doc=120075 |title = For the first time, Latvian agency enters European Fintech Awards as TOP3 Innovative Banking company |publisher = The Baltic Course |date = 28 April 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref><ref name=Bilan>{{cite web |url = http://www.bilan.ch/techno-plus-de-redaction/meilleures-startups-de-scene-fintech-europe |title = Quelles sont les meilleures start-up de la scène fintech en Europe? |publisher = Bilan |language = french |date = 15 March 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
Behaviosec was the winner of the award for the Best European FinTech Company 2016. Winners in the 9 sub-categories were: [[Monese]] (Challenger Banks), Funding Circle (Alternative Finance), Ebury (Payments), Wikifolio (PFM), Everledger (Blockchain), Kreditech (Financial Inclusion), Knip (InsurTech), Backbase (Innovative Banking Software), and Behaviosec (Risk, Intelligence & Security).<ref name=Euro2>{{cite web |url = http://www.fintech.nl/blog/winners-of-european-fintech-awards-2016-announced |title = Winners of European FinTech Awards 2016 announced |publisher = European FinTech Awards |date = 15 April 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
===India=== FinTech Awards is an event organized by the India FinTech Forum along with several startup accelerators. The winners are decided by a panel of industry stalwarts. The event focuses on actual working product demonstrations to encourage innovation and entrepreneurship.
===Italy===
The ''Italian Fintech Awards'' originated from the Grand Prix for Italian startups, held in 2014. The Grand Prix and the Fintech Awards, both organized by CheBanca!, have been geared towards the best Italian fintech startups. The 2016 edition had a call for submission till 31 March. 12 finalists were chosen among the candidates.<ref name=Italia>{{cite web |url = http://smartmoney.startupitalia.eu/chebanca-italian-fintech-awards-2016 |title = CheBanca! Italian Fintech Awards 2016 |publisher = StartupItalia! |language = italian |date = 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
The winner is awarded 25,000 euros, personalized workshops with startup coaches, and a visit to a startup bootcamp in London. In 2016, the co-winners of the ceremony in [[Milan]] were Ovalmoney and eXrade.<ref name=Economy>{{cite web |url = http://www.economyup.it/startup/4341_italian-fintech-awards-vincono-la-startup-di-benedetta-arese-lucini-e-trakti.htm |title = Italian Fintech Awards, vincono eXrade e la startup di Benedetta Arese Lucini |publisher = EconomyUp |language = italian |date = 7 May 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
===Luxembourg===
The first Fintech Lion Awards in Luxembourg, where held on 21 June 2016. Among the candidates, 15 start-ups from Luxembourg were chosen to pitch their projects at the semi-finals in May. Ten of them were chosen for the finals, which will be held under the patronage of Prime Minister [[Xavier Bettel]].<ref name=Luxe>{{cite web |url = http://paperjam.lu/news/fintech-awards-a-vos-dossiers |title = Fintech Awards: à vos dossiers |author = Xavier Bettel |publisher = Paperjam |language = french |date = 10 April 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
===Netherlands===
The first ''Dutch Fintech Awards'' took place at the headquarters of host [[ABN AMRO]] in [[Amsterdam]] in 2015. A 40-member jury gave awards in seven categories.<ref name=RTL>{{cite web |url = http://www.rtlnieuws.nl/economie/home/adyen-wint-fintech-awards |title = Adyen wint Fintech Awards |author = Frederieke Hegger| publisher = RTL Nieuws |language = dutch |date = 20 April 2015 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref> The awards were attended by some 400 national and international fintech investors, companies, experts and executives.<ref name=Emerce>{{cite web |url = http://www.emerce.nl/nieuws/adyen-fintech-company-the-year-2015 |title = Adyen is FinTech Company of the Year 2015 |publisher = Emerce |language = dutch |date = 20 April 2015 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
In 2015, Adyen was the overall winner, receiving the award for a lasting breakthrough in the current payment industry. The winners in particular categories were: AcceptEmail (Payments), Five degrees (Banking IT), Bux (Personal Finance), Bitonic (Bitcoin), Sparkholder (Intelligence & Analytics), Symbid (SME).<ref name=Emerce />
===Switzerland===
The call for submissions for the first ''Swiss Fintech Award'' was published in October 2015. Any company founded by a Swiss citizen or headquartered in Switzerland could participate. A jury of 16 experts chose the top ten enterprises that would be trained in boot camps. The second round was a [[speed dating]] event with the jury and award sponsors in early February 2016. The three finalists pitched their ideas at the financial and economic forum "Fintech 2016" on 31 March 2016. The winner won a cash prize and a stay at the [[Accenture]] Fintech Innovation Lab in London.<ref name=Swiss>{{cite web |url = http://www.netzwoche.ch/de-CH/News/2015/10/02/Registrierungsbeginn-fuer-Swiss-Fintech-Award.aspx |title = Registrierungsbeginn für Swiss Fintech Award |publisher = Netzwoche |language = german |date = 2 October 2015 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
===United Kingdom===
The ''UK Fintech Awards'' ceremony was held in London on 13 April 2016. Sponsored by Bobsguide, the awards recognized achievements across the global financial technology industry.<ref name=Bob>{{cite web |url = http://www.bobsguide.com/guide/news/2016/Apr/21/imagines-innovative-expertise-celebrated-at-2016-fintech-awards/ |title = Imagine's Innovative Expertise Celebrated at 2016 FinTech Awards |publisher = Bobs Guide |date = 21 April 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>
===United States===
In the United States, there are two major award ceremonies.
The ''Benzinga Fintech Awards'' (''BZ Awards'') take place in [[New York City|New York]]. Their purpose is to "showcase the companies with the most impressive technology, who are paving the future in financial services and capital markets." There are 18 awards.<ref name=Benzinga>{{cite web |url = http://benzingafintechawards.com/ |title = Benzinga Fintech Awards 2016 |publisher = Benzinga |date = 18 September 2015 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref> In 2016, more than 25,000 people voted for their favorites among 223 companies from around the globe.<ref name=Sandbox>{{cite web |url = http://fintechsandbox.org/event/benzinga-fintech-awards-2016 |title = Benzinga Fintech Awards 2016 |publisher = FinTech Sandbox |date = 2016 |accessdate = 16 May 2016}}</ref>
The ''Efma Fintech Awards'' highlight the best in class fintech solutions in several categories, with a panel of experts voting on the best solutions. In 2016, the winners were announced at Efma’s Distribution Summit on 14 April 2016.<ref name=Efma>{{cite web |url = https://www.efma.com/index.php/resources/articles/detail/EN/1/509/1-21AEM0 |title = The Fintech Portal and Awards |publisher = Efma |date = 27 January 2016 |accessdate = 24 May 2016}}</ref>

'''First Car Rental''' is the wholly owned [[car rental]] subsidiary of [[Combined Motor Holdings Limited]] (CMH), a JSE-listed investment holding company based in South Africa.
First Car Rental operates out of 51 branches in South Africa and employs over 450 people. First Car Rental’s fleet consists of several vehicle manufacturers including [[Ford]], [[Nissan]], [[Opel]], [[Chevrolet]], [[Toyota]], [[Renault]], [[Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes]], [[BMW]], [[Fiat]], [[Honda]] and [[Volkswagen]]. In 2014, First Car Rental was listed as one of the Top 500 Best Managed Companies in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.top500.co.za/files/2014/03/TOP-500-SECTOR-RESULT-LIST.pdf|title=Top 500 South Africa's Best Managed Companies|date=14 March 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006095338/http://www.top500.co.za/files/2014/03/TOP-500-SECTOR-RESULT-LIST.pdf|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref> As of October 2014, the company has over 6,000 rental vehicles in use in South Africa.
==History== CMH acquired the franchise for the international vehicle rental groups National and Alamo in 1999 and restructured the companies as National Alamo within CMH. In 2008, Europcar purchased the franchise rights to the National Alamo brand in Europe, Asia and Africa.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.businesstravelnews.com/More-News/Europcar-Buys-European-Holdings-Of-National-And-Alamo/?a=btn |title=Europcar Buys European Holdings Of National And Alamo |date=16 November 2006 |accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> This led to CMH restructuring its car rental business in South Africa and registering the subsidiary First Car Rental.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.motormedia.co.za/newsarticle.asp?ID=3834|title=Combined Motor Holdings: The quiet over-achiever...|date=15 April 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006070102/http://www.motormedia.co.za/newsarticle.asp?ID=3834|archivedate=6 October 2014|df=}}</ref>
==Partners== In Europe, First Car Rental is partnered with [[Sixt]] rent a car, which services over 100 different countries.
In August 2014, FlySafair announced First Car Rental as their official car rental partner in South Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://travel.iafrica.com/flights/953198.html|title=FlySafair teams up with First Car Rental|date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref>
==Corporate social responsibility== First Car Rental supports [[The Rhino Orphanage]] – the world’s first NPO engaged in care and rehabilitation of baby [[rhino]] orphaned by [[poaching]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://africageographic.com/blog/worlds-first-dedicated-rhino-orphanage-founded/|title=World's First Dedicated Rhino Orphanage Founded|date=12 March 2012|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sowetanlive.co.za/news/2014/04/16/first-car-rental-wins-award|title=First Car Rental wins award|date=16 April 2014|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref>
In 2013, First Car Rental launched their transport service for students with disabilities at the University of the Free State.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://supportservices.ufs.ac.za/content.aspx?id=697|title=Support Services|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> and sponsored two vehicles for WetNose Animal Shelter in Pretoria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.easterntimes.co.za/bakkie-sponsored-for-animal-rescue/|title=Bakkie Sponsored for Animal Rescue|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref>
